<h1 id="basic-concepts-in-cryptography">Basic Concepts in Cryptography</h1><p><br></p><h2 id="what-is-cryptography?">What is Cryptography?</h2><h3 id="old:"><strong>Old:</strong></h3><p>Cryptography is about hiding the meaning of messages, to protect confidentiality</p><p><br></p><p>It comes from the greek words Kryptòs (hidden) and graphìa (writing)</p><p><br></p><p>Historically it relied on unsound methods, such as Monoalphabetic and polyalphabtic substitutions (caesar's cipher and Vigenères cipher ..)</p><p>These kinds of older methods are classical cryptography.</p><p><br></p><h3 id="modern:"><strong>Modern:</strong></h3><p>Modern cryptography is a science that studies methods to allow secure communication in the presence of adversaries</p><p>It relies on precies mathematical definitions and rigorious proofs to guarantee certain security levels</p><p><br></p><p>Goals of modern cryptography other than confidentiality:</p><ul><li>Message integrity</li><li>Authentication</li><li>Non-repuditation</li></ul><p><br></p><h2 id="cryptosystem">Cryptosystem</h2><h3 id="encryption">Encryption</h3><p>Basic definitions:</p><p>PT =&gt; plaintext</p><p>CT =&gt; ciphertext</p><p><span class="ql-formula" data-value="K_E">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>E</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K_E</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.83333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.13889em;" class="mord mathdefault">P</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> </li></ul><p><br></p><h3 id="classification-of-cryptosystems">Classification of Cryptosystems</h3><p><img src="data:image/png;base64,"></p><p><br></p><h3 id="symmetric-key-cryptosystems:">Symmetric key cryptosystems:</h3><ul><li>The encryption and decryption key is the same</li><li>Alice and Bob must agree on this key before the communication happens</li><li>Can be narrowred down into:</li><li class="ql-indent-1">Stream ciphers: Encryption and decryption process single sumbols of the plaintext and ciphertext</li><li class="ql-indent-1">Block ciphers: Encryption and decryptions work over blocks of fixed lenth of symbols</li></ul><p><br></p><h3 id="public-key-(or-assymetric-key)-cryptosystems:">Public key (or assymetric key) cryptosystems:</h3><ul><li>Different keys for encryption and decryption</li><li>Alice uses Bobs public key <span class="ql-formula" data-value="K_E">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>E</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K_E</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.83333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span style="margin-right: 0.07153em;" class="mord mathdefault">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.32833099999999993em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.5500000000000003em; margin-left: -0.07153em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span style="margin-right: 0.05764em;" class="mord mathdefault mtight">E</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span>  to encrypt, Bob uses his own private key <span class="ql-formula" data-value="K_D">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>D</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K_D</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.83333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span style="margin-right: 0.07153em;" class="mord mathdefault">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.32833099999999993em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.5500000000000003em; margin-left: -0.07153em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span style="margin-right: 0.02778em;" class="mord mathdefault mtight">D</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> to decrypt.</li></ul><p><br></p><p><br></p><h3 id="security-models-of-cryptosystems">Security Models of cryptosystems</h3><p>A security model deines how difficult it is for eve to attack a cryptosystem, it is specified by:</p><ul><li>Adversarial goal: what is Eve's objective, and when an attack can be considered succesful</li><li>Attack model: the amount of information that Eve has on the cryptosystem, the plaintexts and the ciphertexts</li><li>Security level: the (computational) resources Eve has when attacking the cryptosystem</li></ul><p><br></p><p><br></p><h3 id="adversarial-goals">Adversarial goals</h3><ul><li>Total break: Eve is able to discover the decryption key and knows the decryption function. She can decrypt and ciphertext that Alice sends to Bob.</li><li>Partial break; Eve is able to decrypt some ciphertexts with a certain probability, without knowing the decryption key</li><li>Disinguishing break: without knowing the decryption key, Eve is able to distinguish between the encryption of two plaintexts with a probability higher than 1/2</li></ul><p><br></p><h3 id="attack-models">Attack models</h3><ul><li>Known ciphertext attack (KCA): Eve only knows some ciphertexts encrypted with the same unknown key</li><li>Known plaintext attack (KPA): Eve gains access to some pairs of plaintext/ciphertext encrypted under the same unknown key.</li><li>Chosen plaintext attack (CPA): Eve isa ble to choose some plaintexts, and to obtain the correspondering ciphertexts encrypted under the same unknown key</li><li>Chosen ciphertext attack (CCA): Eve is able to choose some ciphertexts, and to obtain the corresponding plaintexts decrypted under the same unknown key</li></ul><p><br></p><h3 id="security-levels">Security Levels</h3><ul><li>Computational security: the best attack that Eve can apply on cryptosystem requires at least Noperations, with N being a very large number</li><li>Provable security: A mathematical problem is reduced to the task of breaking the crpyosystem, Hence, breaking the cryptosystem is at least as difficult as efficiently solving the problem (which is thought to be computationally hard)</li><li>Unconditional security: the cryptosystem cannot be broken under the assumed attack model, even if Eve has infinite computational resources</li></ul><p><br></p><p><br></p><h1 id="historical-ciphers">Historical Ciphers</h1><p><br></p><p><strong>Subsitution cipher:</strong> any character of plaintext from the given fixed set of characters is subsituted by some other character from the same set depending on a key</p><p><br></p><p><strong>Transposition (permutation cipher: </strong> plaintext characters are shifted according to some regular system so that the ciphertext is a permutation of the plaintext</p><p><br></p><h2 id="vernam-cipher-(otp)">Vernam Cipher (OTP)</h2><p>In the vernam cipher the PT (x) is a vector of any length over the binary alphabet (Its a string of 0's and 1's)</p><p>The symmetric key (k) is a binary string of the same length as x.</p><p>The ciphertext is the bitwise XOR of the plaintext x and the key k.</p><p><br></p><p>The Vernam Cipher is also known as the One-Time Pad (OTP): each plaintaxt is encrypter with a <em>different </em>key</p><p><br></p><h3 id="security-of-the-vernam-cipher">Security of the Vernam Cipher</h3><ul><li>The OTP can be proved to be unconditionally secure under known ciphertext atacks</li><li>This property is also called <em>perfect secrecy</em></li><li>Assume that probability distributions Pr[X= x] and Pr[Y=y] are defined on <span class="ql-formula" data-value="P">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">P</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.13889em;" class="mord mathdefault">P</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> and <span class="ql-formula" data-value="C">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span Then:</li></ul><p><img src="data:image/png;base64,"></p><p>In other words, knowing the ciphertext y gives no information on the plaintext x</p><p><br></p><h3 id="perfect-secrecy-of-otp">Perfect secrecy of OTP</h3><p>Shannon's THeorem:</p><p>Let  <span class="ql-formula" data-value="(P,C,K,E,D)">﻿<span contenteditable="false"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>P</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>C</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>K</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>E</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>D</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(P,C,K,E,D)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.19444em;"></span><span style="margin-right: 0.03588em;" class="mord mathdefault">y</span></span></span></span></span>﻿</span> </li></ul><p><br></p><p>-----------------</p><ul><li>The OTP satisfies the condition of Shannon's theorem</li><li>If Eve only knows the ciphertext y, each plaintext x is equally likely</li><li>Hence, the OTP is KCA-unconditionally secure</li></ul><p><br></p><h3 id="limitations-of-otp">Limitations of OTP</h3><p>The one-Time Pad suffers from three major drawbacks, namely:</p><ul><li>The key must be as long as the plaintext</li><li>Keys cannot be reused (hence the name "One-time")</li><li>It is unconditionally secure only against KC, which is the weakest attack model</li></ul><p><br></p><p>These drawbacks severaly limits the use of the OTP in practice</p><p><br></p><h3 id="insert-proper-proof-that-otp-is-perfectly-secret-from-slides-(see-slides-for-now)">Insert proper proof that OTP is perfectly secret from slides (see slides for now)</h3><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p>
